CREATE TABLE `wp_commentmeta` (
  `meta_id` bigint(20) unsigned NOT NULL AUTO_INCREMENT,
  `comment_id` bigint(20) unsigned NOT NULL DEFAULT '0',

  `meta_value` longtext,
  PRIMARY KEY (`meta_id`),

) ENGINE=InnoDB DEFAULT CHARSET=utf8;

CREATE TABLE `wp_comments` (
  `comment_ID` bigint(20) unsigned NOT NULL AUTO_INCREMENT,
  `comment_post_ID` bigint(20) unsigned NOT NULL DEFAULT '0',
  `comment_author` tinytext NOT NULL,
  `comment_author_email` varchar(100) NOT NULL DEFAULT '',
  `comment_author_url` varchar(200) NOT NULL DEFAULT '',
  `comment_author_IP` varchar(100) NOT NULL DEFAULT '',
  `comment_date` datetime NOT NULL DEFAULT '0000-00-00 00:00:00',
  `comment_date_gmt` datetime NOT NULL DEFAULT '0000-00-00 00:00:00',
  `comment_content` text NOT NULL,
  `comment_karma` int(11) NOT NULL DEFAULT '0',
  `comment_approved` varchar(20) NOT NULL DEFAULT '1',
  `comment_agent` varchar(255) NOT NULL DEFAULT '',
  `comment_type` varchar(20) NOT NULL DEFAULT '',
  `comment_parent` bigint(20) unsigned NOT NULL DEFAULT '0',
  `user_id` bigint(20) unsigned NOT NULL DEFAULT '0',
  PRIMARY KEY (`comment_ID`),
  KEY `comment_post_ID` (`comment_post_ID`),
  KEY `comment_approved_date_gmt` (`comment_approved`,`comment_date_gmt`),
  KEY `comment_date_gmt` (`comment_date_gmt`),
  KEY `comment_parent` (`comment_parent`)
) ENGINE=InnoDB AUTO_INCREMENT=2 DEFAULT CHARSET=utf8;
/*!40101 SET character_set_client = @saved_cs_client */;

CREATE TABLE `wp_links` (
  `link_id` bigint(20) unsigned NOT NULL AUTO_INCREMENT,
  `link_url` varchar(255) NOT NULL DEFAULT '',
  `link_name` varchar(255) NOT NULL DEFAULT '',
  `link_image` varchar(255) NOT NULL DEFAULT '',
  `link_target` varchar(25) NOT NULL DEFAULT '',
  `link_description` varchar(255) NOT NULL DEFAULT '',
  `link_visible` varchar(20) NOT NULL DEFAULT 'Y',
  `link_owner` bigint(20) unsigned NOT NULL DEFAULT '1',
  `link_rating` int(11) NOT NULL DEFAULT '0',
  `link_updated` datetime NOT NULL DEFAULT '0000-00-00 00:00:00',
  `link_rel` varchar(255) NOT NULL DEFAULT '',
  `link_notes` mediumtext NOT NULL,
  `link_rss` varchar(255) NOT NULL DEFAULT '',
  PRIMARY KEY (`link_id`),
  KEY `link_visible` (`link_visible`)
) ENGINE=InnoDB DEFAULT CHARSET=utf8;

a co-owner here at WebDevStudios has written yet another helpful WordPress book.  <a href=\"http://www.amazon.com/WordPress-Design-Dummies-Computer-Tech/dp/111854661X/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&amp;ie=UTF8&amp;qid=1380029870&amp;sr=1-1&amp;keywords=wordpress+web+design+for+dummies+2nd+edition\">WordPress Web Design for Dummies (2nd edition)</a> is Lisa&#8217;s 11th dummies book based around WordPress!</p>\n<blockquote>\n<div id=\"outer_postBodyPS\">\n<div id=\"postBodyPS\">\n<div>\n<p><b><a href=\"http://webdevstudios.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/09/Screen_Shot_2013-09-24_at_08.50.40.png\"><img class=\"alignleft size-medium wp-image-7805\" alt=\"Screen_Shot_2013-09-24_at_08.50.40\" src=\"http://webdevstudios.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/09/Screen_Shot_2013-09-24_at_08.50.40-240x300.png\" width=\"240\" height=\"300\" /></a>Updated, full-color guide to creating dynamic websites with WordPress 3.6</b></p>\n<p>In this updated new edition, bestselling <i>For Dummies</i> author and WordPress expert Lisa Sabin-Wilson makes it easy for anyone with a basic knowledge of the WordPress software to create a custom site using complementary technologies such as CSS, HTML, PHP, and MySQL. You&#8217;ll not only get up to speed on essential tools and technologies and further advance your own design skills, this book also gives you pages of great case studies, so you can see just how other companies and individuals are creating compelling, customized, and cost-effective websites with WordPress.</p>\n<ul>\n<li>Shows you how to incorporate WordPress templates, graphic design principles, HTML, CSS, and PHP to build one-of-a-kind websites</li>\n<li>Explains how to create an effective navigation system, choose the right color palette and fonts, and select different layouts</li>\n<li>Reveals how you can tweak existing website designs with available themes, both free and premium</li>\n<li>Provides numerous case studies to illustrate techniques and processes, and the effects you can achieve</li>\n<li>Discusses how you can translate your design skills into paid work</li>\n</ul>\n<p>Want to create cost-effective and fantastic websites with WordPress? This do-it-yourself book will get you there.</p>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</blockquote>\n<div id=\"outer_postBodyPS\">\n<div id=\"postBodyPS\">\n<div>\n<p> We are giving away a copy of this awesome book!</p>\n<h1>How to enter:</h1>\n<ul>\n<li>All you have to do is <strong>comment on this post</strong> about how one of Lisa&#8217;s books has helped you, or why you would like this book to help in your WordPress web design.</li>\n<li>The giveaway with be running from 11 AM EDT today (Tuesday September 24th) until Thursday, September 26th at 3 PM EDT.</li>\n<li>We will announce a winner at 4pm EDT on Thursday the 26th.</li>\n<li>You will receive one copy of WordPress Web Design for Dummies (2nd edition) <strong>autographed</strong> by Lisa Sabin-Wilson.</li>\n<li>US submissions only.</li>\n<li>Employees and family members of WDS are encouraged to submit an entry, but are not eligible to win.</li>\n</ul>\n<p>We look forward to reading about how Lisa&#8217;s books have helped you or why this book would improve your WordPress web design!</p>\n<p>Also, make sure to check out the entire list of books that WebDevStudios has under our belt (with more to come in the not so distant future!) <a The event is happening on Saturday, September 21st and is being held at the University of Baltimore in the Thumel Business Center. We would like to give a big round of applause to the organizers; <a href=\"https://twitter.com/theandystratton\">Andy Stratton</a> and <a href=\"https://twitter.com/BmoreDrew\">Drew Poland</a>, along with the <a href=\"http://2013.baltimore.wordcamp.org/sponsors/\">sponsors</a>, for making this event possible!</p>\n<p>Now, we already know that Brad Williams and Jayvie Canono of WDS will be going to this event, but make sure you check out the entire list of <a href=\"http://2013.baltimore.wordcamp.org/attendees/\">attendees</a> and <a href=\"http://2013.baltimore.wordcamp.org/speakers/\">speakers</a> that you will be learning from and getting to know. Also, have a look at the full <a href=\"http://2013.baltimore.wordcamp.org/schedule/\">schedule</a> so you know which presentations you would like to attend and you can plan accordingly.</p>\n<p>What would a WordCamp be without an after party? When you&#8217;re finished having a long day of cramming your brain full of WordPress knowledge, it&#8217;s time to relax. The after party is being held at the The Waterfront Hotel in Baltimore’s historic Fell’s Point starting at 7:30pm.</p>\n<p>If you plan on attending WordCamp Baltimore 2013, make sure you find Brad and Jayvie in the crowd and say hey. As always, they are looking forward to meeting new people and reunited with the ones they have already 1.1\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"guid\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:32:\"http://webdevstudios.com/?p=7752\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:1:{s:0:\"\";a:1:{s:11:\"isPermaLink\";s:5:\"false\";}}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:11:\"description\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:428:\"Here at WebDevStudios we do a bunch of heavy lifting for clients. It&#8217;s rare for us to install &#8220;XYZ plug-in&#8221; and call it a day. One client wanted to show the total likes, tweets, pageviews, and comment counts, via custom &#8230; <a class=\"more-link\" href=\"http://webdevstudios.com/2013/09/04/display-likes-tweets-pageviews-and-comment-counts-in-posts/\">Continue reading <span class=\"meta-nav\">&#8594;</span></a>\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}}s:32:\"http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/\";a:1:{s:7:\"creator\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:12:\"Greg Rickaby\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}}s:40:\"http://purl.org/rss/1.0/modules/content/\";a:1:{s:7:\"encoded\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:8735:\"<p><img class=\"alignleft size-full wp-image-7765\" title=\"get-social-data\" alt=\"get-social-data\" src=\"http://webdevstudios.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/09/get-social-data.jpg\" width=\"317\" height=\"189\" />Here at WebDevStudios we do a bunch of heavy lifting for clients. It&#8217;s rare for us to install &#8220;XYZ plug-in&#8221; and call it a day.</p>\n<p>One client wanted to show the total likes, tweets, pageviews, and comment counts, via custom buttons, for about 20 posts - <em>on the homepage</em>. Talk about some overhead! I needed to find a fast solution, fast.</p>\n<p>Immediately I got to work investigating how to grab all of this social data. To my surprise, I could not find a single resource that spelled it out. I spent hours on Google and StackOverflow and I&#8217;m happy to share my findings &#8211; all in one place.</p>\n<p>To meet the clients needs, I needed to:</p>\n<ol>\n<li>Query each respective social network&#8217;s API with the post permalink</li>\n<li>Bail if there is an error</li>\n<li>Receive results in either JSON or XML form</li>\n<li>Parse the results and extract our &#8220;total count&#8221;</li>\n<li>Store the total count in transient cache</li>\n<li>Finally, write the total count into our HTML</li>\n</ol>\n<h2>Get total number of Tweets</h2>\n<pre class=\"prettyprint linenums\">/**\n * Get tweet count from Twitter API (v1.1)\n */\nfunction wds_post_tweet_count( $post_id ) {\n\n  // Check for transient\n  if ( ! ( $count = get_transient( \'wds_post_tweet_count\' . $post_id ) ) ) {\n\n    // Do API call\n    $response = wp_remote_retrieve_body( wp_remote_get( \'https://cdn.api.twitter.com/1/urls/count.json?url=\' . urlencode( get_permalink( $post_id ) ) ) );\n\n    // If error in API call, stop and don\'t store transient\n    if ( is_wp_error( $response ) )\n      return \'error\';\n\n    // Decode JSON\n    $json = json_decode( $response );\n\n    // Set total count\n    $count = absint( $json-&gt;count );\n\n    // Set transient to expire every 30 minutes\n    set_transient( \'wds_post_tweet_count\' . $post_id, absint( $count ), 30 * MINUTE_IN_SECONDS );\n\n  }\n\n return absint( $count );\n\n}</pre>\n<p>The above function looks delightfully simple, because it is. I did all five steps in less than 30 lines of code.</p>\n<h2>Get total number of Facebook Likes, Shares, and FB Comments</h2>\n<pre class=\"prettyprint linenums\">/**\n * Get like count from Facebook FQL\n */\nfunction wds_post_like_count( $post_id ) {\n\n  // Check for transient\n  if ( ! ( $count = get_transient( \'wds_post_like_count\' . $post_id ) ) ) {\n\n    // Setup query arguments based on post permalink\n    $fql  = &quot;SELECT url, &quot;;\n    //$fql .= &quot;share_count, &quot;; // total shares\n    //$fql .= &quot;like_count, &quot;; // total likes\n    //$fql .= &quot;comment_count, &quot;; // total comments\n    $fql .= &quot;total_count &quot;; // summed total of shares, likes, and comments (fastest query)\n    $fql .= &quot;FROM link_stat WHERE url = \'&quot; . get_permalink( $post_id ) . &quot;\'&quot;;\n\n    // Do API call\n    $response = wp_remote_retrieve_body( wp_remote_get( \'https://api.facebook.com/method/fql.query?format=json&amp;query=\' . urlencode( $fql ) ) );\n\n    // If error in API call, stop and don\'t store transient\n    if ( is_wp_error( $response ) )\n      return \'error\';\n\n    // Decode JSON\n    $json = json_decode( $response );\n\n    // Set total count\n    $count = absint( $json[0]-&gt;total_count );\n\n    // Set transient to expire every 30 minutes\n    set_transient( \'wds_post_like_count\' . $post_id, absint( $count ), 30 * MINUTE_IN_SECONDS );\n\n  }\n\n return absint( $count );\n\n}</pre>\n<p>The function above is almost exactly the same as the tweet function. We&#8217;re using <a href=\"https://developers.facebook.com/docs/technical-guides/fql/\" target=\"_blank\">Facebook Query Language</a> (FQL) to extract granular data because Facebook&#8217;s <a href=\"https://developers.facebook.com/docs/opengraph/\" target=\"_blank\">Open Graph</a> doesn&#8217;t allow you to extract individual counts based on post&#8217;s permalink. (Read more about getting &#8220;shares&#8221; data via Open Graph on <a href=\"http://stackoverflow.com/a/5700882/226210\" target=\"_blank\">StackOverflow</a>).</p>\n<p>Note: I left &#8220;<em>share_count</em>&#8220;, &#8220;<em>like_count</em>&#8220;, and &#8220;<em>comment_count</em>&#8221; in the example just in case you wanted to mix or match. Just know, &#8220;total_count&#8221; is a sum of the aforementioned totals.</p>\n<h2>Get total number of Pageviews from Jetpack</h2>\n<pre class=\"prettyprint linenums\">/**\n * Get post pageview count\n */\nfunction wds_post_pageview_count( $post_id ) {\n\n  // Check for transient\n  if ( ! ( $count = get_transient( \'wds_post_pageview_count\' . $post_id ) ) ) {\n\n    // Verify we\'re running Jetpack\n    if ( function_exists( \'stats_get_csv\' ) ) {\n\n      // Do API call\n      $response = stats_get_csv( \'postviews\', \'post_id=\'. $post_id .\'&amp;period=month&amp;limit=1\' );\n\n      // Set total count\n      $count = absint( $response[0][\'views\'] );\n\n    // If not, stop and don\'t set transient\n    } else {\n      return \'Jetpack stats not active\';\n    }\n\n      // Set transient to expire every 30 minutes\n      set_transient( \'wds_post_pageview_count\' . $post_id, absint( $count ), 30 * MINUTE_IN_SECONDS );\n\n  }\n\n return absint( $count );\n\n}</pre>\n<p>The above function will ask Jetpack to give us the total pageviews over 30 days for our post.</p>\n<h2>Get total number of Comments</h2>\n<pre class=\"prettyprint linenums\">/**\n * Get post comment count\n */\nfunction wds_post_comment_count( $post_id ) {\n\n  // Check for transient\n  if ( ! ( $count = get_transient( \'wds_post_comment_count\' . $post_id ) ) ) {\n\n    // Verify comments are open\n    if ( comments_open() ) {\n\n      // Get comment count\n      $count = absint( get_comments_number( $post_id ) );\n\n    // If not, stop and don\'t set transient\n    } else {\n      return \'Comments closed\';\n    }\n\n    // Set transient to expire every 30 minutes\n    set_transient( \'wds_post_comment_count\' . $post_id, absint( $count ), 30 * MINUTE_IN_SECONDS );\n\n  }\n\n return absint( $count );\n\n}</pre>\n<p>The function above requires no third-party API and works with Disqus.</p>\n<h2>Create social media icons function</h2>\n<pre class=\"prettyprint linenums\">/**\n * Markup for Social Media Icons\n */\nfunction wds_social_media_icons() {\n	\n  // Get the post ID\n  $post_id = get_the_ID(); ?&gt;\n\n  &lt;div class=&quot;social-icons-wrap&quot;&gt;\n    &lt;ul class=&quot;social-icons&quot;&gt;\n      &lt;li class=&quot;social-icon twitter&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://twitter.com/share?&amp;amp;url=&lt;?php the_permalink(); ?&gt;&amp;amp;text=&lt;?php the_title(); ?&gt;&amp;amp;via=XXXXXXXXXXXXX&quot;&gt;&lt;?php echo wds_post_tweet_count( $post_id ); ?&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;\n      &lt;li class=&quot;social-icon facebook&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=&lt;?php the_permalink(); ?&gt;&amp;amp;appId=XXXXXXXXXXXXX&quot;&gt;&lt;?php echo wds_post_like_count( $post_id ); ?&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;\n      &lt;li class=&quot;social-icon pageviews&quot;&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;?php echo wds_post_pageview_count( $post_id ); ?&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;\n      &lt;li class=&quot;social-icon comments&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;&lt;?php comments_link(); ?&gt;&quot;&gt;&lt;?php echo wds_post_comment_count( $post_id ); ?&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;\n    &lt;/ul&gt;\n  &lt;/div&gt;&lt;!-- .social-icons-wrap --&gt;\n\n&lt;?php }</pre>\n<p>This function is what I used to create the HTML markup to display icons and total counts.</p>\n<h2>Use wds_social_media_icons(); in the loop</h2>\n<pre class=\"prettyprint linenums\">&lt;div id=&quot;primary&quot; class=&quot;content-area&quot;&gt;\n  &lt;div id=&quot;content&quot; class=&quot;site-content&quot; role=&quot;main&quot;&gt;\n\n    &lt;?php if ( have_posts() ) : ?&gt;\n \n      &lt;?php /* The loop */ ?&gt;\n      &lt;?php while ( have_posts() ) : the_post(); ?&gt;\n        &lt;?php get_template_part( \'content\', get_post_format() ); ?&gt;\n        &lt;?php wds_social_media_icons(); ?&gt;\n      &lt;?php endwhile; ?&gt;\n \n      &lt;?php else : ?&gt;\n        &lt;?php get_template_part( \'content\', \'none\' ); ?&gt;\n      &lt;?php endif; ?&gt;\n \n  &lt;/div&gt;&lt;!-- #content --&gt;\n&lt;/div&gt;&lt;!-- #primary --&gt;</pre>\n<p>Now, I can use the function: <em>wds_social_media_icons();</em> anywhere inside the loop, and the counts will show up!</p>\n<p>The functions are split into separate functions, so you can use all &#8211; or none. Totally modular. I hope these examples help you with your next project, and to view the full output of this post, (with loop example) check out <a href=\"https://gist.github.com/gregrickaby/6429669\" target=\"_blank\">this Gist</a>.</p>\n\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}}s:36:\"http://wellformedweb.org/CommentAPI/\";a:1:{s:10:\"commentRss\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:100:\"http://webdevstudios.com/2013/09/04/display-likes-tweets-pageviews-and-comment-counts-in-posts/feed/\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}}s:38:\"http://purl.org/rss/1.0/modules/slash/\";a:1:{s:8:\"comments\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:1:\"1\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}}}}i:3;a:6:{s:4:\"data\";s:54:\"\n		\n		\n		\n		\n		\n				\n		\n		\n		\n		\n\n		\n		\n				\n			\n		\n		\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";s:5:\"child\";a:5:{s:0:\"\";a:7:{s:5:\"title\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:59:\"WebDevStudios’ Take On a WordPress Core Widget UI Refresh\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"link\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:93:\"http://webdevstudios.com/2013/08/14/webdevstudios-take-on-a-wordpress-core-widget-ui-refresh/\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:8:\"comments\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:102:\"http://webdevstudios.com/2013/08/14/webdevstudios-take-on-a-wordpress-core-widget-ui-refresh/#comments\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:7:\"pubDate\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:31:\"Wed, 14 Aug 2013 14:46:43 +0000\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:8:\"category\";a:5:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:8:\"WordCamp\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}i:1;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:9:\"WordPress\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}i:2;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:10:\"contribute\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}i:3;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:8:\"sidebars\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}i:4;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:7:\"widgets\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"guid\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:32:\"http://webdevstudios.com/?p=7670\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:1:{s:0:\"\";a:1:{s:11:\"isPermaLink\";s:5:\"false\";}}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:11:\"description\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:446:\"Let&#8217;s face it &#8211; unless you like devoting your time to clicking, dragging, accidentally letting go of your mouse button, then clicking and dragging again, we all hate the widget management page. With things becoming more and more streamlined with &#8230; <a class=\"more-link\" href=\"http://webdevstudios.com/2013/08/14/webdevstudios-take-on-a-wordpress-core-widget-ui-refresh/\">Continue reading <span class=\"meta-nav\">&#8594;</span></a>\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}}s:32:\"http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/\";a:1:{s:7:\"creator\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:13:\"Corey Collins\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}}s:40:\"http://purl.org/rss/1.0/modules/content/\";a:1:{s:7:\"encoded\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:7292:\"<p>Let&#8217;s face it &#8211; unless you like devoting your time to clicking, dragging, accidentally letting go of your mouse button, then clicking and dragging again, we all hate the widget management page. With things becoming more and more streamlined with each WordPress release, how is it that the widget page remains such a cumbersome, laborious trial of will and patience (not to mention finger dexterity)? I&#8217;m sure we&#8217;ve all complained about it at one point or another, especially when a client wants a bevy of widget areas/sidebars forcing you to try and make your browser scroll while dragging a widget to the bottom of your list.</p>\n<p><img class=\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-7708\" alt=\"Widgets Rageface\" src=\"http://webdevstudios.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/08/widgets-rageface.jpg\" width=\"800\" height=\"382\" /></p>\n<p>We&#8217;ve all complained, sure. And thanks to inspiration garnered from the WordCamp San Francisco contributor day, we&#8217;re now going to do something about it!</p>\n<p>The idea started simply enough &#8211; an easier way to add and configure widgets. Rather than using the drag-and-drop method currently in place, we wanted a straightforward and streamlined approach. The widget area would hold an &#8220;add a new widget&#8221; button that upon clicking, would present a modal window in the same style as the media manager.</p>\n<p><a href=\"http://webdevstudios.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/08/widget-modal-all-widgets.jpg\"><img class=\"size-large wp-image-7703 aligncenter\" alt=\"widget-modal-all-widgets\" src=\"http://webdevstudios.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/08/widget-modal-all-widgets-1024x615.jpg\" width=\"640\" height=\"384\" /></a></p>\n<p>All available WordPress widgets are listed here. Think of the media modal&#8217;s grid presentation of media. When you click on a widget, its fields are presented on the right side of the modal window (in place of the attachment details). Want to add multiple widgets to a widget area at once? Just control/command click or drag to select multiple widgets, then click the &#8220;Add to Widget Area&#8221; button in the bottom right hand corner.</p>\n<p>Could it be any easier? A way to not only do away with the endless struggle of dragging widgets all over the page, but also to edit and add multiple widgets at the same time. Streamlined.</p>\n<p>But why stop there? After all, if we&#8217;re not going to have the widgets on the left side of the widget management page, then we&#8217;re going to need to do a bit of a redesign. We&#8217;re not looking to reinvent the wheel here, but rather piggyback off of another existing area in WordPress the same way we are with the new widget management modal. In this instance, we&#8217;re adopting the same layout as the menu management page.</p>\n<p><a href=\"http://webdevstudios.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/08/widget-admin-page.jpg\"><img class=\"aligncenter size-large wp-image-7704\" alt=\"widget-admin-page\" src=\"http://webdevstudios.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/08/widget-admin-page-1024x615.jpg\" width=\"640\" height=\"384\" /></a></p>\n<p>Instead of displaying every widget area on a page, we&#8217;re going to give importance to the widget area you&#8217;re editing right now. Select a widget area from the dropdown menu and voilà - you&#8217;re looking at your existing widgets and are able to rearrange, remove, and add new widgets quickly and easily. Click the cog to quickly pull up the widget settings:</p>\n<p><a href=\"http://webdevstudios.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/08/widget-modal-active-widgets1.jpg\"><img class=\"aligncenter size-large wp-image-7705\" alt=\"widget-modal-active-widgets\" src=\"http://webdevstudios.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/08/widget-modal-active-widgets1-1024x615.jpg\" width=\"640\" height=\"384\" /></a></p>\n<p>But what is a widget area? As it is now, widget areas are synonymous with registered sidebars, and a registered sidebar is synonymous with a location in the theme. The plan is to abstract widget areas, newly defined as a container for a configuration of widgets, away from the theme locations. This way you can register a sidebar (a holder of widget-areas) in your theme, specify it&#8217;s location(s) in the theme (where that holder of widget-areas should be displayed) and the magical part, from within the WordPress admin choose which widget area that sidebar should display. This opens up a whole slew of opportunities for conditional widget area placement.</p>\n<p><em>(One small caveat that we would like to take note of here is that widget areas will automatically be created and applied to each sidebar registered in the theme. This should help save a step that&#8217;s currently required with menus if all you want to do is have one widget area per registered sidebar.)</em></p>\n<p>We&#8217;re all familiar with the menu management page, so we know that we would need to retool the left hand column to make sense in our widget management page. Posts, Pages, Categories and Taxonomies become a more powerful conditional display options section for your widget area. Right from the WordPress widget management page, you can decide to place your widget area in a specific page template; to display it for specific users; to display it on specific posts, categories and taxonomies; and to override the default widget area used in an existing template. Our hope is that everything that you can accomplish by editing a template file will be able to be accomplished right here in the dashboard.</p>\n<p>This is all fine and dandy so far, but we&#8217;re still not done. Have you ever had the experience of adding a widget to a widget area, only to realize that you need to add the same widget to many other widget areas? What if you want to duplicate an entire widget area without going through and adding and re-configuring every widget again?</p>\n<p>We&#8217;ve got a solution for that with &#8220;Duplicate&#8221; buttons. The widget duplicate button will copy a single widget to another widget area with a couple clicks, saving you the trouble of dragging, dropping, and possibly editing another instance of the same widget all over again. The widget area duplicate button creates an exact duplicate of the current widget area, so you can simply modify the widget settings that you need.</p>\n<p>This is a pretty ambitious project but we&#8217;re confident that WebDevStudios can spearhead the production of this project and we would love to get your help! In keeping with the new philosophy of WordPress development contributions that Matt Mullenweg highlighted in his State of the Word talk at WordCamp 2013 (<a title=\"3.6 and State of the Word\" href=\"http://ma.tt/2013/08/3-6-and-state-of-the-word/\" target=\"_blank\">go see it if you haven&#8217;t!</a>), we plan on working on this as a separate plugin. We have it available as a <a href=\"https://github.com/WebDevStudios/WordPress-Widgets-Refresh\" target=\"_blank\">public repo on our GitHub</a> page and we&#8217;re hosting the discussion over on the <a title=\"WDS Core Development\" href=\"http://core.webdevstudios.com/\" target=\"_blank\">WDS Core Development</a> site. Let us know your thoughts in the comments. We&#8217;d love to have you partner with us in our goal of getting this included in core by WordPress 3.8, tentatively due in December of this year.</p>\n\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}}s:36:\"http://wellformedweb.org/CommentAPI/\";a:1:{s:10:\"commentRss\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:98:\"http://webdevstudios.com/2013/08/14/webdevstudios-take-on-a-wordpress-core-widget-ui-refresh/feed/\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}}s:38:\"http://purl.org/rss/1.0/modules/slash/\";a:1:{s:8:\"comments\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:2:\"39\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}}}}i:4;a:6:{s:4:\"data\";s:48:\"\n		\n		\n		\n		\n		\n				\n		\n		\n\n		\n		\n				\n			\n		\n		\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";s:5:\"child\";a:5:{s:0:\"\";a:7:{s:5:\"title\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:33:\"WDS at WordCamp Grand Rapids 2013\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"link\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:70:\"http://webdevstudios.com/2013/08/12/wds-at-wordcamp-grand-rapids-2013/\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:8:\"comments\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:79:\"http://webdevstudios.com/2013/08/12/wds-at-wordcamp-grand-rapids-2013/#comments\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:7:\"pubDate\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:31:\"Mon, 12 Aug 2013 15:26:58 +0000\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:8:\"category\";a:3:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:4:\"Team\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}i:1;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:8:\"WordCamp\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}i:2;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:9:\"WordPress\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"guid\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:32:\"http://webdevstudios.com/?p=7663\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:1:{s:0:\"\";a:1:{s:11:\"isPermaLink\";s:5:\"false\";}}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:11:\"description\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:405:\"Add another WordCamp to the WDS roster! Our very own Brian Richards is co-organizing WordCamp Grand Rapids 2013, with the help of  Chad Warner, Luke Rumley, and Topher DeRosia. This is the second year in a row that Brian is co-organizing &#8230; <a class=\"more-link\" href=\"http://webdevstudios.com/2013/08/12/wds-at-wordcamp-grand-rapids-2013/\">Continue reading <span class=\"meta-nav\">&#8594;</span></a>\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}}s:32:\"http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/\";a:1:{s:7:\"creator\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:13:\"Melissa Hoppe\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}}s:40:\"http://purl.org/rss/1.0/modules/content/\";a:1:{s:7:\"encoded\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:2809:\"<p><a href=\"http://webdevstudios.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/08/Screenshot_on_8.2.2013_at_11.34.14_AM.png\"><img class=\"alignleft size-full wp-image-7664\" alt=\"Screenshot_on_8.2.2013_at_11.34.14_AM\" src=\"http://webdevstudios.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/08/Screenshot_on_8.2.2013_at_11.34.14_AM.png\" width=\"359\" height=\"244\" /></a>Add another WordCamp to the WDS roster! Our very own <a title=\"Brian Richards\" href=\"http://webdevstudios.com/team/brian-richards/\">Brian Richards</a> is co-organizing <a href=\"http://2013.grandrapids.wordcamp.org/\">WordCamp Grand Rapids 2013, </a>with the help of  <a href=\"https://twitter.com/warnerchad\">Chad Warner,</a> <a href=\"https://twitter.com/lukerumley\">Luke Rumley</a>, and <a href=\"https://twitter.com/topher1kenobe\">Topher DeRosia</a>. This is the second year in a row that Brian is co-organizing this event.</p>\n<p><a title=\"Lisa Sabin-Wilson\" href=\"http://webdevstudios.com/team/lisa-sabin-wilson/\">Lisa Sabin-Wilson</a> will be speaking at <a href=\"http://2013.grandrapids.wordcamp.org/\">WordCamp Grand Rapids 2013</a>. She is speaking on the topic of  <em>“Scoping Projects – A Therapy Session For Those Who Do Client Work”</em>.</p>\n<p><strong>Description:</strong></p>\n<blockquote><p>Attention to detail in your code and design work is important – but before you lay down one single pixel, or one single line of code, you need to make sure that everyone (you, your client, your clients client, etc) are on the same page and make sure you are managing expectations on what the desired project outcome is.</p>\n<p>This 30-40 minute covers hard lessons I’ve learned in a decade of client work – I hope to pass those headaches on to you so you don’t make the same mistakes.</p></blockquote>\n<p>WebDevStudios is excited to announce that we are silver sponsors of WordCamp Grand Rapids! We love WordCamps and know how the people who organize these events rely on the WordPress community for funding these awesome events. We are always happy to help out!</p>\n<p><a href=\"http://2013.grandrapids.wordcamp.org/\">WordCamp Grand Rapids 2013</a> is being held at the Grand Valley State University and runs from Saturday, August 24th through Sunday, August 25th. To attend <a href=\"http://2013.grandrapids.wordcamp.org/\">WordCamp Grand Rapids</a>, be sure to visit to their <a href=\"http://2013.grandrapids.wordcamp.org/attend/\">registration page</a>. Also, follow <a href=\"https://twitter.com/WCGrandRapids\">@WCGrandRapids</a> and look out for the #WCGR hash tag on twitter to get the latest news!</p>\n<p>If you&#8217;re attending WordCamp Grand Rapids this year, make sure you stop and say hello to Brian R. and Lisa. They are, as always, excited to reconnect with people they&#8217;ve already met and get to know those of you they haven&#8217;t met!</p>\n\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}}s:36:\"http://wellformedweb.org/CommentAPI/\";a:1:{s:10:\"commentRss\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:75:\"http://webdevstudios.com/2013/08/12/wds-at-wordcamp-grand-rapids-2013/feed/\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}}s:38:\"http://purl.org/rss/1.0/modules/slash/\";a:1:{s:8:\"comments\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:1:\"1\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}}}}i:5;a:6:{s:4:\"data\";s:45:\"\n		\n		\n		\n		\n		\n				\n		\n\n		\n		\n				\n			\n		\n		\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";s:5:\"child\";a:5:{s:0:\"\";a:7:{s:5:\"title\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:40:\"WordCamp San Francisco 2013 Inspires WDS\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"link\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:77:\"http://webdevstudios.com/2013/08/02/wordcamp-san-francisco-2013-inspires-wds/\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:8:\"comments\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:86:\"http://webdevstudios.com/2013/08/02/wordcamp-san-francisco-2013-inspires-wds/#comments\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:7:\"pubDate\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:31:\"Fri, 02 Aug 2013 18:19:32 +0000\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:8:\"category\";a:2:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:8:\"WordCamp\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}i:1;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:13:\"San Francisco\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"guid\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:32:\"http://webdevstudios.com/?p=7661\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:1:{s:0:\"\";a:1:{s:11:\"isPermaLink\";s:5:\"false\";}}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:11:\"description\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:401:\"The dust is starting to settle from WordCamp San Francisco, but the team here at WebDevStudios has been invigorated and can&#8217;t stop talking about our time in San Francisco. We were lucky enough to be able to have the entire &#8230; <a class=\"more-link\" href=\"http://webdevstudios.com/2013/08/02/wordcamp-san-francisco-2013-inspires-wds/\">Continue reading <span class=\"meta-nav\">&#8594;</span></a>\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}}s:32:\"http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/\";a:1:{s:7:\"creator\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:14:\"April Williams\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}}s:40:\"http://purl.org/rss/1.0/modules/content/\";a:1:{s:7:\"encoded\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:4662:\"<p><a href=\"http://webdevstudios.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/12/wds_group_alcatraz.jpg\"><img class=\"size-medium wp-image-7643 alignleft\" alt=\"The entire WDS team visiting Alcatraz during WordCamp SF 2013\" src=\"http://webdevstudios.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/12/wds_group_alcatraz-300x199.jpg\" width=\"300\" height=\"199\" /></a>The dust is starting to settle from WordCamp San Francisco, but the team here at WebDevStudios has been invigorated and can&#8217;t stop talking about our time in San Francisco. We were lucky enough to be able to have the entire WebDev team make the trip out to San Francisco and we took full advantage including a bunch of team activities along with one great WordCamp. Today, I asked everyone what was their favorite part of our time at WCSF and I thought I would share some of their responses with you:</p>\n<p><em><a href=\"http://webdevstudios.com/team/justin-sternberg/\">Justin</a>: Meeting all the WP minds and hearing some awesome presentations on Saturday.</em><br />\n<em><a href=\"http://webdevstudios.com/team/jayvie-canono/\">Jayvie</a>: Meeting the team and networking, as usual.</em><br />\n<em><a href=\"http://webdevstudios.com/team/greg-rickaby/\">Greg</a>: The lunch!</em><br />\n<em><a href=\"http://webdevstudios.com/team/brian-richards/\">Brian R</a>: Matt showcasing the DMA and Eric Mann&#8217;s talk about GruntJS- he got our entire team excited about automation.</em></p>\n<p>One thing that really stood out to our team is awesome job the WordCamp San Francisco organizers did selecting speakers for the event. There were two huge days filled with so much great WordPress information that you might have thought your head would explode by the end of day two. Some of the more popular technical talks of the weekend (as voted by the WebDev team) are Andrew Nacin: <a href=\"http://2013.sf.wordcamp.org/session/current-user-can-watch-this-talk/\">Current User Can Watch This Talk</a>; Eric Mann: <a href=\"http://2013.sf.wordcamp.org/session/automated-wordpress-development/\">Automated WordPress Development</a>; Josh Bronton: <a href=\"http://2013.sf.wordcamp.org/session/sticks-spit-duct-tape-advanced-rwd-layout-techniques/\">Sticks, Spit &amp; Duct Tape: Advanced RWD Layout Techniques</a> &amp; Mike Schroder: <a href=\"http://2013.sf.wordcamp.org/session/magical-wordpress-management-using-wp-cli/\">Magical WordPress Management using WP-CLI</a>.</p>\n<p><a href=\"http://webdevstudios.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/08/WordPress-and-the-Ten-Year-Itch-Speaker-Deck.png\"><img class=\"size-medium wp-image-7665 alignright\" alt=\"WordPress and the Ten Year Itch    Speaker Deck\" src=\"http://webdevstudios.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/08/WordPress-and-the-Ten-Year-Itch-Speaker-Deck-300x205.png\" width=\"300\" height=\"205\" /></a>There was also a very interesting and humorous presentation from Siobhan McKeown on <a href=\"http://wordpress.tv/2013/07/31/siobhan-mckeown-wordpress-and-the-ten-year-itch-2/\">WordPress And The Ten Year Itch</a> which highlighted her work on the history of WordPress over the past 10 years and how it has grown thanks to the people who have had an itch to make websites better.</p>\n<p>As always a major highlight of WordCamp San Francisco was <a href=\"http://wordpress.tv/2013/07/29/matt-mullenweg-state-of-the-word-2013/\">Matt Mullenweg&#8217;s State of the Word 2013</a>. Matt discussed how there has been a shift in the way WordPress is used and how he believes the shift will continue, focusing on using WordPress as an application framework. He mentioned a project that we have been involved in building, <a href=\"http://badgeos.org/dma-kiosks-badgeos/\">BadgeOS and the DMA Friends relationship management system</a>. He also mentioned the now released <a href=\"http://wordpress.org/news/2013/08/oscar/\">WordPress 3.6</a> and the rapidly progressing plans for WordPress 3.7 and 3.8.</p>\n<p>After hearing Matt&#8217;s State of the Word everyone was really excited for the great things that are to come with future releases of WordPress. With a little nudging from <a href=\"https://twitter.com/nacin\">Nacin</a> to attend Sunday&#8217;s contributor day, the WebDevStudios team started working on a refresh of the widget UI for future inclusion in WordPress core. We plan on providing much more details on this soon, but you can see the <a href=\"http://core.webdevstudios.com/\">current progress</a>!</p>\n<p>If you didn&#8217;t have a chance to attend WordCamp San Francisco in person or virtually be sure to check out the videos on <a href=\"http://wordpress.tv/\">WordPress TV</a>. There are only a few presentations up there now, but I&#8217;m sure they will be adding more soon!</p>\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\n\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}}s:36:\"http://wellformedweb.org/CommentAPI/\";a:1:{s:10:\"commentRss\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:82:\"http://webdevstudios.com/2013/08/02/wordcamp-san-francisco-2013-inspires-wds/feed/\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}}s:38:\"http://purl.org/rss/1.0/modules/slash/\";a:1:{s:8:\"comments\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:1:\"0\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}}}}i:6;a:6:{s:4:\"data\";s:45:\"\n		\n		\n		\n		\n		\n				\n		\n\n		\n		\n				\n			\n		\n		\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";s:5:\"child\";a:5:{s:0:\"\";a:7:{s:5:\"title\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:34:\"WDS Welcomes Scott Kingsley Clark!\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"link\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:70:\"http://webdevstudios.com/2013/08/01/wds-welcomes-scott-kingsley-clark/\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:8:\"comments\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:79:\"http://webdevstudios.com/2013/08/01/wds-welcomes-scott-kingsley-clark/#comments\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:7:\"pubDate\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:31:\"Thu, 01 Aug 2013 14:35:32 +0000\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:8:\"category\";a:2:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:7:\"General\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}i:1;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:4:\"Team\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"guid\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:32:\"http://webdevstudios.com/?p=7649\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:1:{s:0:\"\";a:1:{s:11:\"isPermaLink\";s:5:\"false\";}}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:11:\"description\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:403:\"WebDevStudios would like to welcome another great mind to our ever growing team &#8212; Scott Kingsley Clark! Scott has been developing websites since he was in the 9th grade &#8212; that&#8217;s right.. the ripe age of 15! He has worked &#8230; <a class=\"more-link\" href=\"http://webdevstudios.com/2013/08/01/wds-welcomes-scott-kingsley-clark/\">Continue reading <span class=\"meta-nav\">&#8594;</span></a>\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}}s:32:\"http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/\";a:1:{s:7:\"creator\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:13:\"Melissa Hoppe\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}}s:40:\"http://purl.org/rss/1.0/modules/content/\";a:1:{s:7:\"encoded\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:2255:\"<p>WebDevStudios would like to welcome another great mind to our ever growing team &#8212; <a href=\"http://webdevstudios.com/team/scott-kingsley-clark/\">Scott Kingsley Clark</a>!</p>\n<p><a href=\"http://webdevstudios.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/07/686e5adaeb9ac167131555da31543050.jpeg\"><img class=\"alignleft size-medium wp-image-7650\" alt=\"686e5adaeb9ac167131555da31543050\" src=\"http://webdevstudios.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/07/686e5adaeb9ac167131555da31543050-300x300.jpeg\" width=\"300\" height=\"300\" /></a>Scott has been developing websites since he was in the 9th grade &#8212; that&#8217;s right.. the ripe age of 15! He has worked on hundreds of websites and applications through the years ranging from small sites to enterprise level sites requiring high availability. Scott started working with WordPress in 2007 and has since become invigorated by the fact that he can push his and others&#8217; boundaries on a daily basis. Through his love for WordPress, he has fostered a variety of WordPress plugins both personally and through the companies he has worked with. He enjoys attending and speaking at WordCamps, Meetups, and Conferences that will hopefully soon be expanded to include those around the world. You may have heard about Scott via his work with his passion project, the <a href=\"http://pods.io/\">Pods Framework</a> which is an interface and PHP codebase to easily create, extend, manage, and deploy content types and data within WordPress.</p>\n<p>When his head isn&#8217;t sucked into code, Scott enjoys spending family time with his wife, Cassidy, and his beautiful daughters, Annabelle and Violet. He can also shred some tunes on his Baritone Ukulele through his music project, <a href=\"http://softcharisma.com/\">Soft Charisma</a>. But even when Scott isn&#8217;t coding, he&#8217;s likely still thinking about how to hone his skills, making it easier for others to build with WordPress, and make a difference in other people&#8217;s lives.</p>\n<p>Scott is excited to work with WDS because of its reputation, the extremely talented team, and the difference that it&#8217;s making in the WordPress world.</p>\n<p>We are happy to welcome Scott to our team and are enthusiastic about the talent and experiences he brings to WDS!</p>\n\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}}s:36:\"http://wellformedweb.org/CommentAPI/\";a:1:{s:10:\"commentRss\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:75:\"http://webdevstudios.com/2013/08/01/wds-welcomes-scott-kingsley-clark/feed/\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}}s:38:\"http://purl.org/rss/1.0/modules/slash/\";a:1:{s:8:\"comments\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:1:\"3\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}}}}i:7;a:6:{s:4:\"data\";s:48:\"\n		\n		\n		\n		\n		\n				\n		\n		\n\n		\n		\n				\n			\n		\n		\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";s:5:\"child\";a:5:{s:0:\"\";a:7:{s:5:\"title\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:35:\"WDS@WCSF Brian\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"link\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:83:\"http://webdevstudios.com/2013/07/25/wdswcsf-2013-interview-with-brian-messenlehner/\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:8:\"comments\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:92:\"http://webdevstudios.com/2013/07/25/wdswcsf-2013-interview-with-brian-messenlehner/#comments\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:7:\"pubDate\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:31:\"Thu, 25 Jul 2013 15:49:09 +0000\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:8:\"category\";a:3:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:4:\"Team\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}i:1;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:8:\"WordCamp\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}i:2;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:13:\"San San Francisco 2013! The biggest WordPress shin dig jamboree hootenanny of the year. I&#8217;m showing up about a day late so I&#8217;m kind of bummed about missing all of the great sessions lined up on Friday. I&#8217;m currently on &#8230; <a class=\"more-link\" href=\"http://webdevstudios.com/2013/07/25/wdswcsf-2013-interview-with-brian-messenlehner/\">Continue reading <span class=\"meta-nav\">&#8594;</span></a>\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}}s:32:\"http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/\";a:1:{s:7:\"creator\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:18:\"Brian Messenlehner\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}}s:40:\"http://purl.org/rss/1.0/modules/content/\";a:1:{s:7:\"encoded\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:3297:\"<p><a href=\"http://webdevstudios.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/07/brian-messenlehner.jpg\"><img class=\" wp-image-7638 alignleft\" alt=\"Brian Messenlehner\" src=\"http://webdevstudios.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/07/brian-messenlehner.jpg\" width=\"362\" height=\"453\" /></a>WordCamp San Francisco 2013! The biggest WordPress shin dig jamboree hootenanny of the year. I&#8217;m showing up about a day late so I&#8217;m kind of bummed about missing all of the great sessions lined up on Friday. I&#8217;m currently on vacation in Vermont at a beautiful place called Mile Point on Lake Champlain enjoying time with family and friends. I&#8217;ve spent almost a full week here being (mostly) disconnected from the internet and work which has been very relaxing and rejuvenating for my mind and body. I got to go fishing with my grandfather and my daughter, take all of the family kids out boating, tubing and rock jumping on the lake and witness my son taking his first steps. What better way to end a great vacation other than flying out to San Francisco to WordPress it up and spend the weekend with my other family, the WDS crew. I just hope someone saves me a bed at the house we&#8217;re renting and I don&#8217;t have to sleep in the bath tub or even worse share the bath tub with someone else  ;) It will be great to see everybody and spend some quality time together with the family!</p>\n<p>I remember WDS being born, learning to crawl, learning to walk and starting to run. This year it feels like WDS is flying fighter jets. We have an awesome team of really great people with so much talent and we are building so many cool web applications with great clients. This is the 2nd year getting the WDS crew together at a WordCamp and I hope we will keep the tradition going like an annual family reunion. I&#8217;m so excited to see what&#8217;s in store for WDS in the years to come and what cool people we will work with and what cool projects we will work on.</p>\n<p>O yeah #WCSF&#8230; The schedule looks great! I think I will be spending the majority of my time in the developers and designers track with the exception of <a href=\"http://2013.sf.wordcamp.org/session/bbpress-and-buddypress-what-where-why-who-and-how/\" target=\"_blank\">Beyond the Blog with BuddyPress and bbPress</a> and <a href=\"http://2013.sf.wordcamp.org/session/teaming-up-from-freelance-to-wordpress-agency/\" target=\"_blank\">Teaming Up: From Freelance to WordPress Agency</a>. I&#8217;m looking forward to Matt&#8217;s <a href=\"http://2013.sf.wordcamp.org/session/the-state-of-the-word-2013/\" target=\"_blank\">State of the Word</a>, WordPress has come a very long way in the past few years, it&#8217;s an awesome framework to build web applications on top of and I&#8217;m excited to see what the future holds. I also look forward to wandering around the building talking WordPress with colleagues and potential clients, we met our first WordPress VIP hosted client at #WCSF a few years back. Out of all of the WordCamps I&#8217;ve attended I think the best after party dance offs have been in San Francisco. It must be something in the water or maybe it&#8217;s just the alcohol. What ever the reason, the parties Automattic throws are always awesome! Look forward to seeing all of you and may the WordPress be with you!</p>\n\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}}s:36:\"http://wellformedweb.org/CommentAPI/\";a:1:{s:10:\"commentRss\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:88:\"http://webdevstudios.com/2013/07/25/wdswcsf-2013-interview-with-brian-messenlehner/feed/\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}}s:38:\"http://purl.org/rss/1.0/modules/slash/\";a:1:{s:8:\"comments\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:1:\"0\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}}}}i:8;a:6:{s:4:\"data\";s:45:\"\n		\n		\n		\n		\n		\n				\n		\n\n		\n		\n				\n			\n		\n		\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";s:5:\"child\";a:5:{s:0:\"\";a:7:{s:5:\"title\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:34:\"WDS@WCSF Williams\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}}s:40:\"http://purl.org/rss/1.0/modules/content/\";a:1:{s:7:\"encoded\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:2900:\"<p>I love WordPress.  I love California.  Combine the two and what do you get?  WordCamp San Francisco!</p>\n<p><a href=\"http://webdevstudios.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/07/979893_10152846827925352_117984235_o.jpg\"><img class=\"alignleft size-medium wp-image-7634\" alt=\"979893_10152846827925352_117984235_o\" src=\"http://webdevstudios.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/07/979893_10152846827925352_117984235_o-271x300.jpg\" width=\"271\" height=\"300\" /></a>I am most looking forward to hanging out with the entire WDS team.  Being a 100% distributed company, we rarely get to see each other outside of our virtual office.  The past two years we&#8217;ve made it a point to have a company retreat around a WordCamp.  Last year our entire company attended WordCamp Philly.  This year will be WordCamp San Francisco!</p>\n<p>I&#8217;m also looking forward to seeing all of my WordPress friends at the event.  I&#8217;ve met so many amazing people in the WordPress community over the years, and a good number of those people will be in attendance at WordCamp SF.  I also enjoy meeting new WordPress friends at every event I go to.  It may be someone I&#8217;ve only talked to over Twitter or someone I haven&#8217;t met at all.  Everyone at the event has a passion for WordPress so it&#8217;s always fun hearing their stories, learning about their projects, and just talking WordPress.</p>\n<p>Lastly I&#8217;m very excited about the panel I&#8217;m participating in: <a href=\"http://2013.sf.wordcamp.org/session/teaming-up-from-freelance-to-wordpress-agency/\" target=\"_blank\">Teaming Up: From Freelance to WordPress Agency</a>.  On the panel will be myself, <a href=\"https://twitter.com/jakemgold\" target=\"_blank\">Jake Goldman</a> of 10up, <a href=\"https://twitter.com/alexkingorg\" target=\"_blank\">Alex King</a> of Crowd Favorite, and <a href=\"https://twitter.com/justlikeair\" target=\"_blank\">Shane Pearlman</a> of Modern Tribe with <a href=\"https://twitter.com/photomatt\" target=\"_blank\">Matt Mullenweg</a> as chief moderator.  The panel will discuss the challenges and experiences each business owner had when growing from 1-person to a large WordPress agency.  I&#8217;m looking forward to sharing my experiences when starting WebDevStudios and also learning more about the other companies.</p>\n<p>I will also be roaming the hallways with my brother from another mother <a href=\"https://twitter.com/dremeda\" target=\"_blank\">Dre Armeda</a> doing <a href=\"http://2013.sf.wordcamp.org/2013/07/17/live-stream-attendees-welcome-to-the-hallway-track/\" target=\"_blank\">Hallway Track interviews</a> with attendees and speakers at the event.  If you want to be interviewed by <a title=\"WordPress podcast\" href=\"http://dradcast.com\" target=\"_blank\">DRAD</a> make sure you track us down!</p>\n<p>WordCamp San Francisco 2013 is going to be an amazing event.  If you are attending make sure you say hello!</p>\n\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}}s:36:\"http://wellformedweb.org/CommentAPI/\";a:1:{s:10:\"commentRss\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:74:\"http://webdevstudios.com/2013/07/24/wdswcsf-2013-interview-with-brad/feed/\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}}s:38:\"http://purl.org/rss/1.0/modules/slash/\";a:1:{s:8:\"comments\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:1:\"0\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}}}}i:9;a:6:{s:4:\"data\";s:45:\"\n		\n		\n		\n		\n		\n				\n		\n\n		\n		\n				\n			\n		\n		\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";s:5:\"child\";a:5:{s:0:\"\";a:7:{s:5:\"title\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:36:\"WDS@WCSF 24 Jul 2013 14:00:46 +0000\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:8:\"category\";a:2:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:8:\"WordCamp\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}i:1;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:13:\"San Francisco\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"guid\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:32:\"http://webdevstudios.com/?p=7614\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:1:{s:0:\"\";a:1:{s:11:\"isPermaLink\";s:5:\"false\";}}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:11:\"description\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:379:\"WordCamp San Francisco has always been the end all be all of WordCamps and with that it’s always one of my favorites. After being on the WordCamp circuit for so long, most all of my friends are in the WordPress &#8230; <a class=\"more-link\" href=\"http://webdevstudios.com/2013/07/24/wdswcsf-2013-interview-with-shayne/\">Continue reading <span class=\"meta-nav\">&#8594;</span></a>\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}}s:32:\"http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/\";a:1:{s:7:\"creator\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:14:\"April Williams\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}}s:40:\"http://purl.org/rss/1.0/modules/content/\";a:1:{s:7:\"encoded\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:1902:\"<p><img class=\"alignleft size-full wp-image-7139\" alt=\"Shayne Sanderson Technical Project Manager\" src=\"http://webdevstudios.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/shayne.jpg\" width=\"250\" height=\"300\" />WordCamp San Francisco has always been the end all be all of WordCamps and with that it’s always one of my favorites. After being on the WordCamp circuit for so long, most all of my friends are in the WordPress community and strung out all over the country/world so obviously I don&#8217;t get to see them very often. San Francisco is always a great opportunity to reconnect with most all of my WordPress friends, so besides it being a great event it&#8217;s also like a family reunion for me and I love that!</p>\n<p>I&#8217;m looking very forward to seeing everyone there and also with WDS being a distributed company I&#8217;ve never met some of the folks I work with now. The WDS crew is sharing a large house while in San Francisco so that will be great fun (and likely crazy times) and I&#8217;m looking very forward to hanging out with all of my coworkers.</p>\n<p>As for the conference I think I&#8217;m most looking forward to catching <a href=\"https://twitter.com/cdils\" target=\"_blank\">Carrie Dils&#8217;</a> talk on Collaboration Not Competition. This is a great subject and with so many WordPress developers, plugin/theme authors, etc out there I think this talk will be very beneficial as we sometimes forget that there&#8217;s plenty of work to go around and finding good solid folks to work with (not against) is a great thing for all involved. She&#8217;s also a fellow Texan so there&#8217;s that piece too <img src=\'http://webdevstudios.com/wp-includes/images/smilies/icon_smile.gif\' alt=\':)\' class=\'wp-smiley\' /> </p>\n<p>I&#8217;m really excited to see all of my old friends and make some new ones at WordCamp San Francisco this year &#8211; make sure and some say hi if you see me!</p>\n\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}}s:36:\"http://wellformedweb.org/CommentAPI/\";a:1:{s:10:\"commentRss\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:76:\"http://webdevstudios.com/2013/07/24/wdswcsf-2013-interview-with-shayne/feed/\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}}s:38:\"http://purl.org/rss/1.0/modules/slash/\";a:1:{s:8:\"comments\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:1:\"0\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}}}}}}s:44:\"http://purl.org/rss/1.0/modules/syndication/\";a:2:{s:12:\"updatePeriod\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:6:\"hourly\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:15:\"updateFrequency\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:1:\"1\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}}s:27:\"http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom\";a:1:{s:4:\"link\";a:2:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:0:\"\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:1:{s:0:\"\";a:3:{s:3:\"rel\";s:4:\"self\";s:4:\"type\";s:19:\"application/rss+xml\";s:4:\"href\";s:41:\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/webdevstudios\";}}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}i:1;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:0:\"\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:1:{s:0:\"\";a:2:{s:3:\"rel\";s:3:\"hub\";s:4:\"href\";s:32:\"http://pubsubhubbub.appspot.com/\";}}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}}s:42:\"http://rssnamespace.org/feedburner/ext/1.0\";a:3:{s:4:\"info\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:0:\"\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:1:{s:0:\"\";a:1:{s:3:\"uri\";s:13:\"webdevstudios\";}}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:14:\"emailServiceId\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:13:\"webdevstudios\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"x
